contents.context:
Eight people, most of them students, have been confirmed of COVID-19 after coming into contact with an instructor working at a private academy in Incheon who had contracted the virus at a nightclub in Itaewon, Seoul.
Incheon City said Wednesday that five high-schoolers, one middle-school student, a parent and a colleague have tested positive.
Those students were either attending the same private academy as the infected instructor, or were being tutored by the instructor.
The instructor had reportedly lied about their workplace during an earlier investigation.

"Incheon City is going to sue the infected patient number 102 based on the contagious disease prevention act as the patient lied during the investigation about their job, where they had been, and that they taught students."

Currently, over one-thousand people are being tested in relation to the case,as they had attended the same churches in Incheon as two of the eight people.

As of midday Wednesday, the total number of infections related to the nightclubs in Itaewon had reached 119.
Seventy-six of them were infected at the clubs, while the rest were secondary infections.
Seoul had the most cases, followed by Gyeonggi-do Province.
But the cluster infection has spread out to other regions too, including Busan and Jeju.
South Korea reported 26 new COVID-19 cases on Wednesday, most of which were related to the cluster infection in Itaewon.
The total number of infections in the country now stands at 10,962.
Yoon Jung-min, Arirang News.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Students in Incheon confirmed to have COVID-19 after contact with instructor infected in Itaewon
Updated: 2020-05-13 17:20:41 KST

contents.context:
Seoul resident Hwang Hyeok takes the subway every day, but ever since the start of the COVID-19 outbreak, he has been worried about people not wearing masks.

"I take the subway every day and when I see people who are not wearing masks, it makes me worried and frustrated."

But starting from Wednesday, people must wear masks on crowded subway trains in the capital.
This comes as Seoul Metropolitan Government has expanded its "distancing in daily life" measures to include the use of public transport.

"We are trying our best to keep the subway environment safe such as by disinfecting trains more than 4 times a day. So as long as citizens follow this new measure of wearing masks, I believe it will be safe to take the subway."

When carriages are classed as "congested", people will be asked to put on masks, and further boarding will be restricted.
This level of congestion is when carriages reach over 150 percent of their recommended quota, based on the weight of 160 people in a carriage.
Sensors in the carriages can detect this weight and show current congestion levels.

For those who have forgotten to bring a mask from home, stations have placed vending machines that sell masks at street price.

"I totally support the change. I feel more relieved that people now have to wear masks on the subway. I also carry around extra masks just in case I forget to bring one."

Seoul Metro is also planning to provide passengers with daily congestion forecasts for the following day on its website and social media like Twitter at 6 PM.
For the busiest lines including lines 2, 4 and 6, extra trains will run during rush hour.
Kim Sung-min, Arirang News
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Seoul city makes it compulsory to wear masks on crowded trains
Updated: 2020-05-13 17:20:12 KST

contents.context:
On what's supposed to be her first day back at school, high school senior Byeon Sung-eun is heading to a shared study room.
The start of school has been postponed once again, from May 13th to the 20th.
To Byeon, that one week delay impacts a major life event the college entrance exam.

"By now, I should have had already taken a mock version of the test, and based on that, I'd be preparing strategically for the actual exam. But that's not happening right now."

And because of the delay, a hectic semester awaits.
At least 5 major exams are planned, and midterms are set to take place just two weeks after students get back to the classroom.

"Of course that's not enough time to prepare. But what's more concerning is that most online classes are provided by EBS, the educational broadcast channel, but the actual tests will be made by our teachers at school. That means the material will be different."

Also, summer break will be shortened, leaving students with less time to spend in college applications.

All students can do at this point is take their classes online and study by themselves while waiting for school to get back to normal.

"Some students are also attending private academies.
Here in Seoul's Daechi-dong, where many academies are concentrated,…teachers and students are busy trying to fill the gap caused by the lack of school."

"Seniors have less time to prepare for the college entrance exam because they have to catch up with their school classes. That puts them at a disadvantage, physically and psychologically, compared to graduates who are re-taking the exam."

There's growing speculation that the college entrance exam will be rescheduled again, but the education ministry says that won't happen as long as schools open this month.
Lee Kyung-eun, Arirang News.
Reporter : kelee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
School delay means high school seniors lose time to prepare for college exam
Updated: 2020-05-13 17:20:05 KST

contents.context:
South Korea aims to locate all visitors to the Itaewon nightclubs and bars affected by the recent cluster infections within this weekin order for them to be tested for COVID-19.
Speaking at a government meeting on Wednesday, Prime Minister Chung Sye-kyun said there are still some people who could not be reachedbut it's just a matter of time before they are tracked down.
He has urged for those people to get tested willingly and added that no personal information will be recordedto prevent any issues of privacy.
Should they test positive for COVID-19, only their recent travel history will be checked so to prevent any secondhand transmissions.
Among those whose cell phones had connected to base stations in the close vicinity of the clubs between April 24th and May 6th, 11-percent were foreign nationals.
In response, Seoul has pledged to distribute details of the new COVID-19 measures in 12 different languages and will ask the relevant embassies to encourage their citizens to get tested.
Seoul Mayor Park Won-soon said the number of people getting tested daily in Seoul is 8 times larger due to the Itaewon community transmission.
But, has expressed concern over young people in their twenties and thirties who have a wide travel range and may have visited enclosed spaceswhere the virus can be easily transmitted.
Meanwhile, three other nightclubs in Itaewon have been confirmed to have cases of COVID-19.
Mayor Park warned that if things get worse, stricter measures to ensure that entertainment facilities are following quarantine guidelines could be implemented.
Hong Yoo, Arirang News.
Reporter : yoohong@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Gov't targets tracing all visitors to Itaewon clubs this week for virus tests: PM
Updated: 2020-05-13 17:19:54 KST

contents.context:
President Moon Jae-in will deliver a keynote address at the virtual World Health Assembly next week.
Upon the WHO Director-General's request, the South Korean president will share South Korea's experience combating COVID-19 based on three principles openness, transparency and democracy, as Asia's representative with other WHO-member nations.
He is also expected to call for global cooperation and solidarity to help overcome the COVID-19 pandemic.
President Moon will become the first South Korean president to be a keynote speaker at the decision-making body of WHO.
Reporter : kimmj@arirang.com
contents.headline:
President Moon to give keynote speech at upcoming virtual WHO Assembly
Updated: 2020-05-13 17:19:49 KST

contents.context:
-Welcome.
-Hello. I want to pay 50,000 won in advance.
More and more "good customers" paying in advance to help small business owners
The Good Customer Campaign helps small business owners struggling because of COVID-19
This good customer campaign is where local residents pay in advance at stores they frequent
and also purchase extra to share with neighbors.
It is a consumption promotion campaign that local residents voluntarily participate in to help our economy.
Customers pay a certain amount in advance at restaurants
as a promise to visit again in the future
-Thank you for the meal. I would like to pay 100,000 won in advance.
-Yes, okay.
The campaign is much-needed for small business owners
When operating a store, there are expenses like wages and other fixed costs.
Paying in advance has helped lessen the burden of these expenses so I think it's good.
I think it would be nice for more small businesses to get involved in this program.
Reporter : cinejenna910@naver.com
contents.headline:
VJ 'Good customers' pay in advance to help small businesses
Updated: 2020-05-13 17:19:14 KST

contents.context:
The Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirmed today that it has identified nearly 120 COVID-19 infections linked to nightclubs in a popular nightlife district in the South Korean capital.
Bars and clubs have been indefinitely closed nationwide and extensive digital tracing is underway with authorities combing through mobile phone data, credit card statements and CCTV footage to identify the thousands who visited the nightclubs between April 30th and May 6th and remain unaccounted for.
One week since the country officially relaxed its social distancing measures, could this mean South Korea, one of the world's top examples for how to combat the coronavirus, may soon become the poster child for the dangers of reopening a country?
It's the topic of our News In-depth tonight with Dr. Alice Tan, Internist at MizMedi Women's Hospital.



Dr. Tan, can you believe exactly one week ago today you and I were sitting right here discussing the country's new 'distancing in daily life' measures talking about malls, restaurants, the Han Riverside Park already bustling with people and you airing caution. Watch out for cluster infections is what you said, I believe. Look at where we are now. Was this inevitable?

What about this latest cluster of cases that can be traced back to the Itaewon area concerns you the most?

The KCDC announced yesterday that they have now identified two people who first showed symptoms as early as on May 2nd which could mean the Itaewon cluster may have "various epicenters or sources."
What does this mean and how does this complicate containment efforts for the health authorities?

It makes me wonder how else could the country have reopened up to avoid such breakout?

The other problem, though, is that at least one of the clubs patient number one from this Itaewon cluster visited was one that catered to members of the LGBTQ.
And, that might make those who attended the nightclubs reluctant to come forward or be identified by the government. How can these hurdles be overcome?

Due to these cluster infections, school reopenings which were set to begin in a staggered fashion in South Korea have been postponed once again by a week. High school seniors were initially supposed to be back at schools today. They won't be back until next Wednesday and even that isn't for certain, either. From a medical professional's point of view, what is the best way forward? I mean, kids will have to return to schools at some point. What is a good, scientific marker for that?

If and when our 5.5 million students go back to schools, what should be the 'new normal' in classrooms?

Then again, news of children fatalities from a rare but potentially lethal inflammatory syndrome that could be linked to COVID-19 are being reported although few in numbers.
Is this something we should be alert about?

The latest spike in cases shows how difficult it is to control the spread of this virus once strict lockdown measures have been lifted and the many complications that can arise when a country is opened up before a vaccine or an effective treatment for COVID-19 is found.
Until an effective vaccine is developed, is there an exemplary model that we could perhaps adopt and adapt?

Dr. Alice Tan, our favorite medical expert keeping us safe and sound in this time of pandemic, many thanks as always for speaking with us. We appreciate it.
Reporter : jenmoon@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
New COVID-19 Cluster Stokes Fear of 2nd Wave in S. Korea
Updated: 2020-05-13 15:23:40 KST

contents.context:
The South Korean government will be making the first payments today of the COVID-19 emergency relief funds.
Those getting the deposits today are people who applied on Monday, when applications started.
The payments will come in the form of points on your credit or debit card.
Others applying throughout this week will get theirs on a rolling basis.
It's hoped that the money will help boost consumer spending amid the outbreak.
It needs to be spent by August 13th, otherwise it'll be donated to support those who lost their jobs or been put on unpaid leave.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Emergency COVID-19 relief fund available to people in S. Korea from Wednesday
Updated: 2020-05-13 13:15:09 KST

contents.context:
Senior defense officials from South Korea, the U.S. and Japan held a video conference Wednesday to discuss collaborating on a response to COVID-19 as well as the nuclear and missile threats posed by North Korea.
The 12th annual Defense Trilateral Talks were initially scheduled to take place in Japan, but, because of the pandemic, were held online.
Seoul's Deputy Defense Minister Chung Suk-hwan and his U.S. and Japanese counterparts reaffirmed the importance of trilateral cooperation in upholding security.
They agreed to meet again online at a later date.
Reporter : jiyeonkim@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
S. Korea, U.S., Japan defense talks held virtually on Wednesday
Updated: 2020-05-13 13:14:10 KST

contents.context:
Our top story this afternoon.
South Korea reported 26 new cases of COVID-19 on Wednesday, …many linked to clubs in Seoul's nightlife district of Itaewon.
Twenty-two cases were community transmissions and four imported.
Total infections in South Korea now stand at ten,nine-hundred-62.
The country reported one new COVID-19 death, …bringing the death toll to two-hundred-59.
More than 19-thousand people are being tested.
Due the cluster infection, …companies like Samsung Electronics are urging their employees to voluntarily report to the authorities if they visited Itaewon between late April and early May.
Reporter :
contents.headline:
S. Korea reports 26 new COVID-19 cases Wednesday after new cluster infection
Updated: 2020-05-13 10:01:42 KST

contents.context:
A multilateral cooperation body initiated by South Korea has been launched on a joint COVID-19 response.
It's dubbed the Group of Friends of Solidarity for Global Health Security.
Seoul's foreign ministry said some 200 professionals across 30 different countries went online late Tuesday for the inaugural conference.
It was jointly chaired by South Korea among others for the frank sharing of information on global health security.
South Korea's Foreign minister Kang Kyung-wha said she hoped the group will serve as an active channel for boosting cross-border cooperation.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Multilateral cooperative COVID-19 group led by S. Korea launches via videoconference
Updated: 2020-05-13 10:00:08 KST
